problem: South is in 3NT. After cashing the diamonds and hearts, East is squeezed in spades and hearts. How should declarer plan the play?
options: Run diamonds and hearts in the right order to squeeze East
Lead clubs to set up dummy's suit
Duck a heart at trick one
answer: Run diamonds and hearts in the right order to squeeze East
explanation: Declarer should cash the diamonds and then the heart winners, forcing East to discard a spade guard. This creates an extra trick.

problem: South is in 6NT. Declarer counts 11 top tricks (spades 2, hearts 3, diamonds 4, clubs 2). How can South make the 12th trick?
options: Cash the diamonds and hearts, then cash clubs to squeeze East in spades or clubs
Give up a club early to establish an entry
Play a long club immediately to set up tricks
answer: Cash the diamonds and hearts, then cash clubs to squeeze East in spades or clubs
explanation: Plan: declarer cashes all four diamond winners and the three heart winners (rectifying the count). East must keep guards in spades (Q T 9 8) and clubs (Q T 7 6). When declarer then cashes the two top clubs (A, K), East is forced to discard from spades or clubs. If East abandons a spade guard, dummy's J becomes good; if East abandons a club guard, dummy's J (or South's remaining club) becomes good. That produces the 12th trick.

title: South to Play
problem: What is the correct opening lead?
explanation: Leading ♦A is correct to establish tricks quickly.

title: Declarer Play
problem: West leads ♥4. What is South's best plan?
explanation: Ducking preserves a stopper and keeps control against East's hearts.
